section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background, engage children with a song, and introduce vocabulary (clings, hauls).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, How do some animal parents carry their babies?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand and use a growing number of prepositions; Respond to instructional language.
Use increasingly complex sentence structures.
Focus attention (self-regulation); Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Understand differences between living and nonliving things.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children use prepositions and complete sentences to talk about animal families.
Guide children to talk about how different animals take care of their young.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do animals help their babies learn, live, and grow?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What animals and their babies do you see in this book?
What animal can you pretend to be? How does that animal care for its babies?
Look at the pictures of animal families. How many babies does each animal family have?
What is your favorite animal? Can you draw that animal and its babies?
What materials can you use to build an animal parent and baby?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word loon? Can you write it?
Can you use blocks to make a place for a baby animal to sleep?

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder focus attention and introduce vocabulary (curiosity, transports).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Baby on Board.
Read closely to practice the Mind Builder.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Respond to instructional language.
Use increasingly complex sentence structures.
Focus attention (self-regulation); Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Understand differences between living and nonliving things.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Motivation and Creativity; Executive Function

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children recall details from the book to answer questions about animal families.
Encourage children to pose their own questions about animal families to show curiosity.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do animals help their babies learn, live, and grow?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you show an animal that is taking care of its baby?
Can you act like a mother otter who is transporting her pup?
Can you show me an animal that has three babies?
Has a parent transported you somewhere like school or the park? Can you draw or write about it?
Can you draw your favorite animal taking care of its baby?
Can you sound out the word baby? What letter sound do you hear at the start of the word baby?
Can you use blocks to show how an opossum mother transports her babies?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Baby on Board: How Animals Carry Their Young by Marianne Berkes, illustrated by Cathy Morrison. Text copyright © 2017 by Marianne Berkes. Illustrations copyright © 2017 by Cathy Morrison. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Dawn Publications. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Motivation and Creativity; Executive Function

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill Make a Connection and introduce vocabulary (remains, prepares).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Baby on Board and asking the guiding question, How are animal parents and human parents the same?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Respond to instructional language.
Use increasingly complex sentence structures.
Focus attention (self-regulation); Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Understand differences between living and nonliving things.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children make connections between how human parents and animal parents care for their children.
Help children talk about how different animals care for their babies.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do animals help their babies learn, live, and grow?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you name two books that are about how animals take care of their babies?
How do you think a mother dog cares for her puppy? Show me.
How many babies will the animal have if she has one more baby?
How do human parents care for their children? Can you write or draw about it?
How are animal parents and human parents the same? Write or draw an animal and human parent taking care of their babies.
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of alligator?
The mother manatee remains close to her calf. Can you show what that means using blocks?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Baby on Board: How Animals Carry Their Young by Marianne Berkes, illustrated by Cathy Morrison. Text copyright © 2017 by Marianne Berkes. Illustrations copyright © 2017 by Cathy Morrison. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Dawn Publications.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_materials-caption.tg_materials-caption_book-title-Ital: Big Chart of Big Ideas: The Chicks Say, “Pio, Pio, Pio”

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to sing about animal families and introduce vocabulary (chicks, shelter).
Guide children to talk about how different animals help their babies live, learn, and grow.
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Respond to instructional language.
Use increasingly complex sentence structures.
Focus attention (self-regulation) Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Understand differences between living and nonliving things.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Invite children to act out scenes from The Chicks Say, “Pio, Pio, Pio.”
Challenge children to sort picture cards in “Shelter” and “Not a Shelter” groups.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do animals help their babies learn, live, and grow?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Is the animal in the book doing a good job at caring for its babies? How can you tell?
If you were a hen, where would you hide your chicks to keep them safe? Why is that a good hiding place?
Can you put the animal families in order from smallest to biggest?
Why do you think the hen in The Chicks Say, “Pio, Pio, Pio” is a good mother? Can you write about it?
Can you make a finger puppet of a chick?
What letter sound do you hear at the beginning of the word hen? Can you write it?
Can you use blocks to make a place for chicks to sleep? Why is that a good place for them?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Baby on Board: How Animals Carry Their Young by Marianne Berkes, illustrated by Cathy Morrison. Text copyright © 2017 by Marianne Berkes. Illustrations copyright © 2017 by Cathy Morrison. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Dawn Publications.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to have children act out animals from the book and to introduce vocabulary (hatched, balancing).
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Respond to instructional language.
Use increasingly complex sentence structures.
Focus attention (self-regulation); Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: “How does your favorite animal take care of its babies?”
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do animals help their babies learn, live, and grow?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: If you wrote a book about animal families, what animals would you put in it?
Pretend to be an elephant mother. What would an elephant mother do?
If we had a class pet, like a rabbit, how would you take care of it?
Can you write a story about an alligator family? What would they do?
Can you create a kangaroo with a pouch for a joey? What materials do you need?
What sound does a lion make? What letter sounds do you hear when you make that sound?
Can you use blocks to build a place for a penguin dad to keep his egg warm, so he doesn’t have to balance it on his feet?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Baby on Board: How Animals Carry Their Young by Marianne Berkes, illustrated by Cathy Morrison. Text copyright © 2017 by Marianne Berkes. Illustrations copyright © 2017 by Cathy Morrison. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Dawn Publications.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Demonstrate understanding of terms used in the instructional language of the classroom.
Use complete sentences of four or more words and grammatical complexity, usually with subject, verb, and object orders.
Sustain attention to personally chosen or routine (teacher-directed) tasks until completed.
Remain focused on engaging group activities for up to 20 minutes at a time.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss the relationship of organisms to their environments.

Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss the relationship of organisms to their environments.

Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
